article.description:
Nicole Ohlde sees no reason why Kansas
State can't stifle opponents this well in every game.
article.headline: Kansas State wins 10th straight game
article.linkText: Fourth-ranked Kansas State easily routs Colorado
article.story:
MANHATTAN, Kan. (AP) -- Nicole Ohlde sees no reason why Kansas
State can't stifle opponents this well in every game.

	   Kendra Wecker had 18 points and 10 rebounds, Ohlde scored 15,
and fourth-ranked Kansas State held (No. 23 ESPN/USA Today, No. 24 AP) Colorado to a
school-record 15 points in the first half of a 61-36 victory
Saturday.

	   "Overall, we wanted to crowd the lanes and play total team
defense,'' Ohlde said. "If we continue to play defense like that,
we should be able to do that every day.''

	   Kansas State (15-1, 2-0 Big 12) never trailed and won its 10th
straight game.

	   The Buffaloes (11-2, 1-1) trailed 34-15 at halftime, their
lowest point total in a half in school history. Colorado scored 18
in a half against Iowa State in 1998.

	   The Buffaloes made just 17 percent of its field-goal attempts in
the first half, also a school record.

	   "I don't have a whole lot to say about it,'' Colorado coach
Ceal Barry said. "What was going through my head is that we need
to make our shots. We were getting nice shots. We were just
short.''

	   The Buffaloes went on an 8-0 run to start the second half,
cutting a 22-point deficit to 14. But Kansas State's Amy Dutmer hit
a 3-pointer with 15:17 left that sparked an 11-0 run and put
Colorado away for good.

	   Megan Mahoney added 14 points for the Wildcats.

	   Kate Fagan led Colorado with 10. The Wildcats held Colorado's
leading scorer, Tera Bjorklund (averaging 18 points) to just six
points.

	   "It was very pleasing to see our team play defense like that,''
Kansas State coach Deb Patterson said. "We're understanding how
important our defense is. That's the statement tonight.''
